chapter.title: The command line
chapter.para: While Xubuntu comes with graphical user interfaces to accomplish most tasks, sometimes you might need a command line to achieve your goal -- or to achieve it faster.

section.title: Running commands with administrative rights
section.para: When working on the command line, any command can be run as an administrator by prefixing the command with sudo. Sudo will remember your password for 15 minutes to allow you to perform multiple administrative tasks without being prompted for a password each time.

note.para: If the program you wish to run as an administrator is graphical, such as the Mousepad text editor, you should obtain a root prompt before launching the desired program, running the command sudo -i for that effect, even if you are running the application from the command line.

warning.para: Be careful when using sudo; you might damage your system if you type the wrong command! As a general rule, only use sudo when absolutely necessary. When you use sudo from a terminal, be sure to either close it when you have finished, or type exit to continue using that terminal with normal access powers.

section.para: For more information on sudo, see the sudo page on the Ubuntu community wiki.

section.title: Common commands
section.para: Basic terminal commands are outlined below (square brackets indicate substitutions):

seglistitem.seg: Shows information about the packages in the repository. Common commands are the search and show commands
apt-cache search web browser or apt-cache show firefox

Manages packages in apt. Common commands are install to install a package, remove to remove a package, purge to remove a package and the configuration, and autoremove which will also remove unneeded packages
Copies a file (or files) to a directory or to overwrite another file
Tells you the date and time in many different formats, timezones, and conversions.
Opens a text file in an editor
Terminates programs with a specified PID. If you don't know the PID you can use pidof
Much like the one above, except you specify the programs name
Shows the contents of a text file
Lists files in a directory. Lists files in the current directory if none is specified
Removes files or directories. Be very careful with this command! With the -r option, it removes all files and directories recursively!
Downloads files to current directory. The -N option can be useful for checking to see if a file on the server is newer than the one you have locally, see man wget for more information.
